jBIest Mary, would his lips have spoke, but they
Were still in death; and his dark eye fell glaz'd
And coldly set meath its unstrring lid
And she, the fond one, knelt beside him still,
Gazing with burning eye, yet shed no tear,
And then she bow'd her head, and buried close
Her face, while from her heart went up to Hcav'n
A silent pray'r, that God would grant her


strength


In this dark hour of desolating thought
And none but He can tell the inward strife,
The burst of thought, that agoniz'd her heart
And then she rose with calm and holy look,
Yet lingerd still beside his couch, and pressd
Once more the lips still clear to her, though pale
And cold and still, they answered not her kiss.
But there was one, who stood UNMARKED the
Her spor,iye, boy. whose glec was chasten'd


down,


He knew not why, till from his eye tear
Sprung forth, and coming to the bed, he took
Ills mothers hand, and said unconsciousy,
"Mother, how long till father will awake"
And then burst forth from the seal'd spring Of


grief


The tears that she had thought she would re-


strain,


For she had ncrv'd herself to bear her wo,
And watchd until her heart grew strong and firm,
But ah! she could not brook, unmov'd, that voice
And look OF her far boy, petWlHt tear
And smile, that came so sudden on her hcart;'--
1t spoke to her Of Joys departed, long.
And hopes deccv'd, and SORROWS yet TO come,
And all the utter darkness Of her fate;
And tears Aow'd fast and long, and chok'd the


pray'r


That would have risen for her orphan hoy.


And thus it is with womsn-her fond heart
Must still be plac'd in perfect trust on some
False dream of Joy, some cloudlet of the sky
Which fancy throwshigh DER our heads in youth,
And then must see it melt away, and leave
A dark'ning thunder cloud that bursts lis folds,
And in its fiery storm skaters her hopes.
She hath no second chance, for all is risk'd
At once and if she fails, she fails for aye.
Yet still so fond, so weak, SO slight thing,
Shrinking from e'en the summer wind, and one
Who seems as made for man to watch and guard,
Will brave the blasts ofadverse fate and unnov'd;
And by the strong endurance of her love,
Will rise, with mind elastic, from the storm
Which lays the pride Of manhoods daring lows
And tho the lov'd the chosen one should turn
In utter scorn away, yet will she cling
Where first she twn'd; and if at last she meet
But one kind word, will deem her wrongs repaid,
And, still confding, prove the faithful one.
D. Y. L.

We commenced the ascent BY winding


road paved with brick. 1t is sufficiently wide
to admit carriage and horses; and ladies', 1t
is said, have often rode up on mules. There
are no steps, and the fatigue OF ascending is
the same as that of toiling up steep hill
Emerging from this passage, on to the root,
a very extraordinary scene presented itself
to us. We found ourselves on large plain,
surrounded by domes in all directions. a
long.roofed shed extended along the centre
ASCENT OF ST. PETER'S.-RoM

Man is strong-woman is beautiful. Man
is daring and confdrnt-woman is diHident.
and unassuming. Man is great in action
woman in suffering. Man shines abroad
woman at home. Man talks to convince
woman to persuade and please. Man has
rugged heart-woman soft and tender one.
Man prevents misery-woman relieves it.
Man has sciencc-woman taste. Man has
judgment-woman sensibility. Man is a be-
ing of iustice--woman of mercy.

The careful consort rules her household well,
Her husband governs with gentle sway,
And courts her lov'd embrace, what home-felt


JOY,
What inward comforts seize her raptur'd breast
But if he, scornful, Sights her converse sweet,
IT'S better for her far to die than live.
Man, when oppressed with black domestic cares,
Ranges abroad to seek relief, and meets
The fellowship of some companions dear;
But helpless, hapless woman, when denied
Those tender joys, which from her husbands


love


She Justly Claims, must seek it no where else.
If, when

of this plain, which had the appearance of
work. house, and from which men OCCASION
ally came out. On either side of us arose
two domes, larger and more beautiful than
the rest; and Immediately behind US tower
ed the great dome itself. A heavy ba]us-
trade surrounds the whole roof: in front
stood the colossal statues of the Apostles
We clambered up the baustrade in order
to take a nearer view of these sacred person.
ages, and were astonishcd to find what
"huge misshapen" beings they were. What
had appeared from the pavement below to
be finely sculptured statues, now exhibited
their real characters-large blocks OF stone.
bound together with iron braces, and so
rudely carved, that one is puzzled to tell the
difference between the fingers and thumbs.
The great dome arises directly from the
centre of the roof; nothing can be more ma
| jcstic than it's appearance from this place
simple. beautiful and grand: nothing to dis
gust or fatigue the eye: the more one re-
CARDS it, the more imposing!does it become,
| it is not like St. Paul's, too heavy for the
roof, but stands in perfect harmony with eve-
~ thing around. The bebolder is not start
led with the idea of its weight; because the
place he stands on, is as firm as the earth it"
self. Between each of the windows project
two pillars. In this, if any thing, there is
fault; the pillars support nothing, and there
| fore seem useless; but SO perfect Is the fous
ensemble, that the most fastidous taste
would be ashamed to find fault.


1 The ascent of the dome commences by a
| fight of steps ON the outside. We then en-
ter and continue the ascent by a magnificent
stone stair way. We were first introduced
into the whispering gallery, which extends
arounds the interior. The communication
of sound is perfect. The first thing that
surprised us on entering this gallery, was
the coarsncss of the Mosaic. From below,
it appeared as fine as the pictures which a
dorm the affairs in the interior; but from this
gallery it has the appearance of huge pieces
! of coIored glass, thrown carelessly upon the
mortar. We ascended again, and after
wearisome Journey came to the second gal
| lery which surrounds the dome at the top OF
the arch: from this place, the view below Is
terrifying; the dome recedcs from under
you and YOU feel as though standing on the
brink of frightful precipice. Though
railing surrounds it, our fears overcome our
Judgment: we could not approach the rail-
ing, but shrunk back under the wall, with
that feeling of horror and dread winch a
man experiences when he finds himself sud-
denly on precipice, over which another
step would plunge him. The passage no"
becomes narrower. After ascending few
minutes longer, the guide opened door,
and told US to look down. We were now at
the very extreme height OF all.


'rhc picture Of the Deity, which from the
pavement below is hardly distinguishable,
was within our reach; it was huge, coarse
and inelegant. The people moving on the
pavement below. appeared less than Lillipu-
tians. The height is so dizzy, that the
Guide has to hold US while looking forward,
and will not permit us to remain but two or
three minutes. We assembled and reached
the lantern, a small room above the dome,
in which is kept an album. to insert the
names of yisjters Continuing our ascent,
we soon became involved in darkness. and
squeezing through a narrow passage. ana up
n ncrpendicular iron ladder, we enter the
ball. Here terminates the journey. But the
ball is not the least wonderful apartment we
have visited. though not certainly the most
comfortable or elegant. 1t is close. dark,
and hot; few loopholes are made to admit
of any view. The size of this bail is sur
prising. Standing on tiptoe. we could not
touch the top--twelvc men nigh. stand in it,


What situation enclosed in ball, perch
ed ON the apex of lofty dome. The
air abo''e, around and beneath us the roar
ing of the wind around this insulated apart
mcrt. seemed to threaten its, and our safety.


We therefore bade it adcu, and descend


ing through the same narrow passage, stop
ned on the outside to breathe the pure air
Of these upper regions. lofty balustrade
surrounds the lantern, just above the arch OF
the dome, enclosing wide and safe promen-
ade. From this point, magnificent pros
pcct extends on all sides. Rome, ancient
and modern--the desolate Campagna-thc
Sabine and Tiburtine mountains-Albanus,
sacred in classic history-Soracte like a
wave on the curl" in the distance-and the
sea skrting the western horizon. all broke
upon us at once. We could trace the Ii
Der to its mouth-we fancied we could dis
tinguish the spot where Eneas landed. The
wars Of Turnnus we're fought over on the
plain which extended below us. The tenn
plcs of old Rome seem to arise from the ru"
ins-cities spring up on the desolate waste
armies were moving in and out of the gates
the temple of Jupiter glittered from the
distant summit of Albanus-the busy hum ot
millions that pcopled old Rome. arose in the
air and antiquity herself threw off her dusty
rags, and arose in all the beauty OF youth.

| bearing and uuerrelsome disposition. His
duelling propensites, however kept him out
of all the first clubs in London, and render
ed him at once an object ofterror and of ha-
tired; and, even when he was introduced at
the Court of France, where single combat
was not SO much reprehended as IN Great
Britain. the young monarch (the unfortunate
Louis XVI.) could not help showing his ab-
horrence of protessed duelst. by utterlng
most deserved sarcasm on Fitzgerald, and
by refusing to admit him second time to
his lcvec. The gentleman who introduced
him (thc English Ambassador,) having
said, ~ have the honor to introduce to your
Majesty, Mr.. Fitzgerald, an Irishman of
high descent, who in his time, has success
lively fought no less than eighteen duels, and
always killed his man." the King replied,
"Monsieur l. l'Ambassadeur, have read your
famous English history of Jack the Giant
hiiler; and think it may be greatly improv-
ed by adding this Irishman's life, by way OF
appendix. Let him retire." His Majesty
! further observed to the Ambassador, in the
duelist's hearing, that if MIR. Fitzgerald
showed disposition to quarrel with any OF
his subjects, he should order him to quit
France in "a hours.


But to avoid further depression, the writer
has to state, that Fitzgerald having once ap-
Piled to Admiral Keith Stewart to propose
him as candidate for Brookcs' and the wor-
thy Admiral we'll knowing that he must Ell
ther fight or comply with his request, chose
the latter alternative. Accordingly, OH the
night in which the baloting was to take
place, (Which was only mere form in this
case, for even Keith Stewart himself had re-
solved to black ball him,) the dueilist ac-
companied the gallant Admiral to St. James
street, and waited in the room below whilst
the suffragcs were taking, in order to know
the issue.


The ballot was soon over, for without hes
itation each member threw in a black-baH,
and when the scrutiny took place, the COM
pany were not little amazed to find not c.
ven one white one among the whole num-
ber. However. the point being carried mem.
con. the grand affair now was, as to which
of the members had the hardihood TO an
nounce the same to the expectant candidate
No one would undertake the office, for the
announcement was sure to produce a chal-
lenge; and duel with fighting Fitzgerald
had in almost every case been fatal to his
opponents. The general opinion, however,
was, that the proposer. Admiral Stewart.
should convey the intelligence, and that in
as gen,eel terms as possible. But the Ad-
mral, who was certainly OIL all proper occa-
sions very gallant officer, was not inclined
! to go on any such embassy. mo gentlemen,
said he, proposed the fellow, because
knew you would not admit him; but have
no inclination to risk my life against that OF
ma(nan." "But, Admiral" replied the
Duke of Devonshire, "there being no white
ball in the box, he must know that youhaye
black balled him as well as the rest, and he
is sure to cali you out at all events" This
was poser for the poor Admiral, who sat,
silent for a few seconds, amidst the half
suppressed litter of the members; at length.
Joining in the laugh against himself, he ex-
claimed, upon my soul! pleasant job I've
got into. D--n the fellow!--No matter
wont go; let the waiter tell him that there
was one black ball, and his Dane must be
put up again if he wishes It," This plan ap-
pearcd so judcious, that all concurred in its
proprlety accordingly, he was, in few
minutes, despatched on the mission.


In the mean time, Mr.. Fitzgerald showed
evident symptoms of impatience. at being
kept SO long from his "dear friends" above
stairs; and frequently rang the bell to know
the state Of the poll. On the first occasion
he thus addressed the waiter who answered
his summons: "Come here, my tight little
| fellow; do you know if am chose yeti" Il
really can't say, sir, replied the young man;
but III sec." "There'sa nice nttle man.
be quick, dye see, and I'll give ye sixpence
when We come with the good news" Away
went the little man; but he was in no hurry
to come back, for he. as well AS all his fel-
lows, was sufficiently aware of Fitzgerald's
violent temper, and wished to come in con
tact with him as seldom as possible.


The bell rang again, and to another wal
ter the impatient candidate put the same
question-'Am / chose yet, 7vaiter?'-' Fhe
5allotting is not over yet, Sir replied the
man. Not over yeti exclaimed Fitzgerald.
But sure there is no use of balotting at all,
when my dear friends are unanimous for me
to come in.-Run, my man, and. let me know
how they are getting on


After the lapse of another quarter Of an
hour the bell rang so violently as to produce
a contest among the poor servants, as to
whose turn it was next to visit the lion in his
den; and MIR. Brooks seeing no alternative
but resolution. took the message from the
waiter who was descending the staircase.
and boldly entered the room with the coffee
ecuipagc in his hand. Ibid you call for cof-
fee, sir?' said Mr.. Brookes, smarty.-----
"D--n your coffee. snr, and you too.'' an
swercd Mr.. Fitzgerald in a voice which
made the hosts blood curdle in his veins; 81
want to know, sur. and tina, without one mo-

you'll find me the best customer in your
house; but there must be small matter of
mistake in my election; and l should not
wish to be SO ungenteel as to take my safe a.
mong my dear friends up stairs until that
mistake is duly rectiied, you'll step up and
make my complimentsto the gentlemen, and
say as it is only mistake of one black ball,
they will be so good as to waive all ceremo-
ny on my account, and proceed to re-elect
their humble servant without any more de-
lay at all; SO now, my dear Mr.. Brookcs,
you may put down the coffee, and I'll be
drinking it while the new election is going
| on"


| Away went Mr.. Brookes, glad enough to
escape with whole bones for this time at
least. On the announcement of his errand
to the assembly above stairs, many Of the
members were panic struck; for they clear
| iy foresaw that some disagrceable circum-
stance was likely to be the finale of the farce
which they had been playing. Mr.. Brookes
stood silent for some minutes, waiting for
an answer, whilst several of the members
whispered and laughed, in groupes, at the
ludicrous figure which they all cut. At
length, the Earl of March, afterwards the
Duke of Queensbury, said aloud, d,--"Try the
effect of tzvo balls: hang his Irish impudence,
if two black balls dent take effect upon him,
don't know what wil.' This proposition
met with unanimous appreciation, and Mr..
Brookes was ordered to communicate it ac-
cording!y.


On re.entcring the waiting room, Mr..
Fitzgerald rose hastily from the chair, and
seizing him by the hand, eagerly inquired,
"Havr they elected me right now. Mr..
Brookesl" 81 hope no offence, Mr. Fitzge-
rald," said the landlord. "but am sorry to
Inform you, that the result of the second ball
loting is, that tsoo black balls were dropped
in, sir" "Sure then," exclaimed Fitzgerald.
s'there's now tzvo mistakes instead of one
Go back, my dear friend and tell the hon.
orabe members that it is very unciyil thing
to keep a gentleman waiting below stairs,
with no one to keep him company but HIM
self, whilst they are enjoying themselves
with their champagne, and their cards. and
their tokay, up above. Tell them to try it
again, and hope they will have better luck
next time, and make no more mistakes, be-
cause it is getting late, and zyontbe chose
tonight at all. So Mr.. Brookes be off with
yourself, and iave the door open till I see
what despatch you make"


Away went Mr.. Brookes for the last time.
On announcing his unwelceme errand. every
one saw that palliative measures only pro-
longed the dilemma; and General Fitzpat-
rick proposed, that Breokes should tell him
mis- Cause was iOl)SlCoob AOt hHdt HS hdo OCCA
black 6ailcd all oUer, from head to foot, and
it was hoped by all the members that Mr..
Fitzgerald would not persist in thurstng
himself into society where his company was
dsclned.'


This message, it was generally belived,
would prove sickener, as it certainly would
have done to any other candidate under SIM
liar circumstances. Not so however, to
Fitzgerald, who no sooner heard the pur-
port of it than he exclaimed, "Oh, Iperceive
it is mistake altogether, Mr.. Brookes, and
must see to the rectfying of it myself
there's nothing like daHng with principals,
and so I'll step up at once. and put this
thing to rights. without any more unneces-
sarv delay"


In spite Of Mr.. Brooks rcmonstrance,
that his entrance into che club room was a.
gaiust all rule and etiquette, Fitzgerald
found his way up stairs, threatening to
throw the landlord over the banisters for en-
deavoring to stop him. He entered the room
without any further ceremony than bow.
and saying to the members, who Indignantly
rose up xt this most unexpected intrusion,
Your servant gentlemen l beg you will
be sated." Walking up to the Fireplace,
he thus addressed Admiral Stewart $50,
my dear Admiral. Mr.. Brookes informs ME
that have been elected three times" "You
have been ballotted for, Mr., Fitzgerald. but
am sorry to say that you have not been
chosen" said Steward. Well, then" repli-
ed the duellist. "did you black-ball me!"--
my good SIR" answered the Admiral,
show could you suppose such thing"-
"Oh, suhhosed no such thing. my dear fell
low; only wanted to know who it was that
dropped the black balls in by accident as it
were"


Fitzgerald now went up to each individu-
al member, and put the same question ser'a-
tim, "Did you black-ball me, sur'" until he
made the round Of the whole club: and it
may we'll be supposed, that in every case ne
obtained similar answers to that OF the al
miral. When he had finished his inquis'-
ton, he thus addressed the whole body, who
preserved as dead and dread silence as the
urchns at parish school do on Saturday.
when the pedagogue orders A.,lf score Of
them to be horscd for neglectinE their catr-
chism, which they have to repeal to the par
son on Sunday :--"You see, gentlemen, that
as none of you have black -balled me, ! mast
be chose; and it is Misther Brookes that has
made the mistake. But was conyinced &C
it from the beginning, and am only sorry
that so much time has been lost, and honor
able gentlemen prevented from ENJOYING
each others company sooner. WanRsr!

Curious Historical FGcf.-During the
troubles in the reign of Charles the first. a
country girl came to I.ordon, in search OF
place as a servant mad, but not succeeding
she hired herself to carry out bear from IA
brew house, and was one ofthcsc called tub
wamen. The brewer observing good look
ing girl in this low occupation, took her in
to his family as servant; and after short
time married her; but he died while yet she
was young woman, and left her the bulk
Of his fortune. The business of the brewe-
ry was dropped, and 10 the young woman
was recommended Mr.. Hyde, as skilful
lawyer to arrange her husbands affairs
Hyde. who was afterwards the great Earl
of Clarendon, finding the widows fortune
very considerable. married her--of this mar
riagc there was no other issue than daugh.
ter, who was afterwards the wife of James
II. and mother of Mary and Anne, Queens
of England.

DEATHS icy grasp was laid upon him now,
And ftfully beneath the tyrant's touch,
yifes current was congealing in his veins,
He was too weak to utter all his thoughts,
But some faint murlnuring from his lips escap'd,
Which none but she might hears yet still his


eyes,
Undimm'd spalse forth the fondness of his heart;
And vet sometimes would strange expression
Flash out beneath his dropping heavy lid,
And he would turn his eyes away from her,
And press convulsively her hand in his,
As tho some maddening thought shot thro' his


brain,
Then turn to her again a troubled look,
And send forth all his rising soul in one
Uncam yet fond and halfimploring glance.
What secret feeling crossed his bosom them
saw them once, when in their youthful prime,
When their first dreams of love and life were


bright
With hope, and fragrant flowers were springing


up


Along their pathway through smiling world,
No blightning fell upon their sunny hopes,
To bar the pledging or their hearts fond


thoughts,


And soon their mutual faith and VOWS were


scard-


She gave her heart, her all in confidence
To him who vow'd to love thro' veal or wo;
And when she fondly laid her head upon
His manly breast, she deem'd that o'cr their love
And bliss, no dark'ning cloud of fate would


comet
But though in youth within his heart no thought,
Save of her angel loveness then dwelt
And he had bowd his soul before the shrine,
In all the fond idolatry of love.


There came at last a change across their fate
For when the open gulelessness of youth
Had pass'd to manhood's darker brow Of care,
And he had mingled with the selfish crowd,
The stainless streams of early noble feeling
Changed their first freshness to ming taint;
And now the home that he was wont to call
His paradise was left for haun,s of mirth;
And he would hold his midnight revellings,
Startling the silence of the night by wild
And heartless joyance, till his heart had lost
All trace of purity-then HE him home,
And chide his once ador'd till she would weep,
An he would wake her infant then, to blend
1t wailing with her tears Of bitterness.
And she-,he injurd onc-her heart had swelled
In silence with IFS load of nk'rns griefs,
Until she might no longer keep it down
And then twas broken.-Yet she murmurd not,
Nor told her plant to any save to Heaven,
But calmly drank her bitter cup of wo;


And when her daily lot was still to bear
Unkindness and abuse, she answered not,
Save by her tears, and meeklv bore it all,
And strove TO still her agony ofheart.


And thus he held his waywarlncss to her,





Upon him; for the oft drain'd bowl at last
Had brought its never falling cnrse-and then
The strong endurance Of her love shone forth,
And, all her wrongs forgetting, she became
lowering angel round his couch of pain;
And without one reproaching word or look;
Fondy she tended him, as tho he ne'er
Had dash'd her cup of earthly happiness.-
And now his heart was soften'd and subdu'd:
ne felt that he had wrong'd her-and the stings
Of self.unbraidiner srnnte him he fhnuUht
upon her patient sufferancc of his hate,
And And how she was repaying all her wrongs
With fond devotedness when all the rest
forsook him in his hour of deepest need
And he would oftentimes have crav'd of her
forgiveness of his ills-but she would stop
his words, and with smile would say to him
me past was buried in oblivion.
hut now he felt that life was ebbing fast,
And that he could not leave the world in peace,
without he easd his bosom of its load
ofguilt-and therefore had his eyes such wild
and troubled looks; and when he took her hand
from off his brow, and laid it on her breast,
20 20 still the beatings of her bursting heart,
ra'h'rlng his Weekend powers, so as to throw
INTO INTO, his last attempt some strength of mind,
WI WITH tone so changed from that of by-past time,
mat mat she half started at its hollow sound,
nc sad; 81 know that soon my heart must stop
.s beatings, and be still at deaths cold touch
1nV-hearme now--for l must speak this once,
now now have wrong'd thee, and to pray that this
my MY last departing hour may hear thee bless
NO. Mono that dare not ask thy blessing
aay hear thee pardon him whose tortur'd heart
ran well aton'd for all its crimes,-if pain


ana suffering can atonement make for sin.


tcannot tell thee all that fills my breast,


90. oryoce and sight are falling fast way


S''oP down, and look once more as thou were
,o wont,


n ntnou wilt pardon me.'' She knelt beside


ins bed, and laid her pallid cheek on his,


Th Tha Kindly said, "Oh, speak not thus my love
rhe past IS all forgotten;-nay look up


-"ou must not leave me now."-A groan burs


forth


nan. ms IS too kind-my heart will burst-one kiss

From The Massachusetts, Yeoman.
THE WIFE-A SKETCH.

Almost all women are captivated by talent;
especially those for whose pleasure, in par
ticular, its possessor may exert it. Nothing
can be more delightful to them, because no.
thing can be more flattering; and fiattery is
the key to all hearts. Want OF handsome
person, or even of good looks. is for the
most part forgotten, or willingly pardoned,
in the man of talent. The eye of woman
does not require to be dazzled as well as her
mind; Il speak of general instances.) The
same cannot be said of virtuous qualities
In SO much higher esteem does human vani-
ty hold talent than virtue. Good looks,
combined with vapd intellect. will win few
women, unless they are equally vapid with
the object of their admiration.
TIE LADIES, FRIEND.

And then she bow'd her head, and buried close
Her face, while from her heart went up to Hcav'n
A silent pray'r, that God would grant her


strength


In this dark hour of desolating thought
And none but He can tell the inward strife,
The burst of thought, that agoniz'd her heart
And then she rose with calm and holy look,
Yet lingerd still beside his couch, and pressd
Once more the lips still clear to her, though pale
And cold and still, they answered not her kiss.
But there was one, who stood UNMARKED the
Her spor,iye, boy. whose glec was chasten'd


down,


He knew not why, till from his eye tear
Sprung forth, and coming to the bed, he took
Ills mothers hand, and said unconsciousy,
"Mother, how long till father will awake"
And then burst forth from the seal'd spring Of


grief


The tears that she had thought she would re-


strain,


For she had ncrv'd herself to bear her wo,
And watchd until her heart grew strong and firm,
But ah! she could not brook, unmov'd, that voice
And look OF her far boy, petWlHt tear
And smile, that came so sudden on her hcart;'--
1t spoke to her Of Joys departed, long.
And hopes deccv'd, and SORROWS yet TO come,
And all the utter darkness Of her fate;
And tears Aow'd fast and long, and chok'd the


pray'r


That would have risen for her orphan hoy.


And thus it is with womsn-her fond heart
Must still be plac'd in perfect trust on some
False dream of Joy, some cloudlet of the sky
Which fancy throwshigh DER our heads in youth,
And then must see it melt away, and leave
A dark'ning thunder cloud that bursts lis folds,
And in its fiery storm skaters her hopes.
She hath no second chance, for all is risk'd
At once and if she fails, she fails for aye.
Yet still so fond, so weak, SO slight thing,
Shrinking from e'en the summer wind, and one
Who seems as made for man to watch and guard,
Will brave the blasts ofadverse fate and unnov'd;
And by the strong endurance of her love,
Will rise, with mind elastic, from the storm
Which lays the pride Of manhoods daring lows
And tho the lov'd the chosen one should turn
In utter scorn away, yet will she cling
Where first she twn'd; and if at last she meet
But one kind word, will deem her wrongs repaid,
And, still confding, prove the faithful one.
D. Y. L.

full articles.headline:
From the MeaD Monthly Magazine.
TIE CLUB OF ST. JAMES'S.
full articles.article:
Whilst on the subject Of sinister admis-
sion to the Club, the writer cannot do better
than relate the very singular and whimsical
manner in which Mr.. Arthur Fitzgerald
forced his way into Brookes'. Thisperson-
age, it is we'll known. though nearly related
to one of the first families in Ireland (Lein-
ster,) was publicly executed in the year
1886, for murder which he had cooily pre-
meditated; and which he and others perpe-
tratetfin most cruel and cowardly manner


The fame, or rather inhmy, which encir-
cled his brows, from hal ling been the sur
vivor in = great many duels, became at
length the cause Of he most ferocious
haugh.iness, and greatly increased his over

full articles.headline: ASCENT OF ST. PETER'S.-RoM
full articles.article:
We commenced the ascent BY winding


road paved with brick. 1t is sufficiently wide
to admit carriage and horses; and ladies', 1t
is said, have often rode up on mules. There
are no steps, and the fatigue OF ascending is
the same as that of toiling up steep hill
Emerging from this passage, on to the root,
a very extraordinary scene presented itself
to us. We found ourselves on large plain,
surrounded by domes in all directions. a
long.roofed shed extended along the centre

Man is strong-woman is beautiful. Man
is daring and confdrnt-woman is diHident.
and unassuming. Man is great in action
woman in suffering. Man shines abroad
woman at home. Man talks to convince
woman to persuade and please. Man has
rugged heart-woman soft and tender one.
Man prevents misery-woman relieves it.
Man has sciencc-woman taste. Man has
judgment-woman sensibility. Man is a be-
ing of iustice--woman of mercy.

full articles.headline: If, when
full articles.article:
The careful consort rules her household well,
Her husband governs with gentle sway,
And courts her lov'd embrace, what home-felt


JOY,
What inward comforts seize her raptur'd breast
But if he, scornful, Sights her converse sweet,
IT'S better for her far to die than live.
Man, when oppressed with black domestic cares,
Ranges abroad to seek relief, and meets
The fellowship of some companions dear;
But helpless, hapless woman, when denied
Those tender joys, which from her husbands


love


She Justly Claims, must seek it no where else.

full articles.headline: APRIL 26, 1927
full articles.article:
of this plain, which had the appearance of
work. house, and from which men OCCASION
ally came out. On either side of us arose
two domes, larger and more beautiful than
the rest; and Immediately behind US tower
ed the great dome itself. A heavy ba]us-
trade surrounds the whole roof: in front
stood the colossal statues of the Apostles
We clambered up the baustrade in order
to take a nearer view of these sacred person.
ages, and were astonishcd to find what
"huge misshapen" beings they were. What
had appeared from the pavement below to
be finely sculptured statues, now exhibited
their real characters-large blocks OF stone.
bound together with iron braces, and so
rudely carved, that one is puzzled to tell the
difference between the fingers and thumbs.
The great dome arises directly from the
centre of the roof; nothing can be more ma
| jcstic than it's appearance from this place
simple. beautiful and grand: nothing to dis
gust or fatigue the eye: the more one re-
CARDS it, the more imposing!does it become,
| it is not like St. Paul's, too heavy for the
roof, but stands in perfect harmony with eve-
~ thing around. The bebolder is not start
led with the idea of its weight; because the
place he stands on, is as firm as the earth it"
self. Between each of the windows project
two pillars. In this, if any thing, there is
fault; the pillars support nothing, and there
| fore seem useless; but SO perfect Is the fous
ensemble, that the most fastidous taste
would be ashamed to find fault.


1 The ascent of the dome commences by a
| fight of steps ON the outside. We then en-
ter and continue the ascent by a magnificent
stone stair way. We were first introduced
into the whispering gallery, which extends
arounds the interior. The communication
of sound is perfect. The first thing that
surprised us on entering this gallery, was
the coarsncss of the Mosaic. From below,
it appeared as fine as the pictures which a
dorm the affairs in the interior; but from this
gallery it has the appearance of huge pieces
! of coIored glass, thrown carelessly upon the
mortar. We ascended again, and after
wearisome Journey came to the second gal
| lery which surrounds the dome at the top OF
the arch: from this place, the view below Is
terrifying; the dome recedcs from under
you and YOU feel as though standing on the
brink of frightful precipice. Though
railing surrounds it, our fears overcome our
Judgment: we could not approach the rail-
ing, but shrunk back under the wall, with
that feeling of horror and dread winch a
man experiences when he finds himself sud-
denly on precipice, over which another
step would plunge him. The passage no"
becomes narrower. After ascending few
minutes longer, the guide opened door,
and told US to look down. We were now at
the very extreme height OF all.


'rhc picture Of the Deity, which from the
pavement below is hardly distinguishable,
was within our reach; it was huge, coarse
and inelegant. The people moving on the
pavement below. appeared less than Lillipu-
tians. The height is so dizzy, that the
Guide has to hold US while looking forward,
and will not permit us to remain but two or
three minutes. We assembled and reached
the lantern, a small room above the dome,
in which is kept an album. to insert the
names of yisjters Continuing our ascent,
we soon became involved in darkness. and
squeezing through a narrow passage. ana up
n ncrpendicular iron ladder, we enter the
ball. Here terminates the journey. But the
ball is not the least wonderful apartment we
have visited. though not certainly the most
comfortable or elegant. 1t is close. dark,
and hot; few loopholes are made to admit
of any view. The size of this bail is sur
prising. Standing on tiptoe. we could not
touch the top--twelvc men nigh. stand in it,


What situation enclosed in ball, perch
ed ON the apex of lofty dome. The
air abo''e, around and beneath us the roar
ing of the wind around this insulated apart
mcrt. seemed to threaten its, and our safety.


We therefore bade it adcu, and descend


ing through the same narrow passage, stop
ned on the outside to breathe the pure air
Of these upper regions. lofty balustrade
surrounds the lantern, just above the arch OF
the dome, enclosing wide and safe promen-
ade. From this point, magnificent pros
pcct extends on all sides. Rome, ancient
and modern--the desolate Campagna-thc
Sabine and Tiburtine mountains-Albanus,
sacred in classic history-Soracte like a
wave on the curl" in the distance-and the
sea skrting the western horizon. all broke
upon us at once. We could trace the Ii
Der to its mouth-we fancied we could dis
tinguish the spot where Eneas landed. The
wars Of Turnnus we're fought over on the
plain which extended below us. The tenn
plcs of old Rome seem to arise from the ru"
ins-cities spring up on the desolate waste
armies were moving in and out of the gates
the temple of Jupiter glittered from the
distant summit of Albanus-the busy hum ot
millions that pcopled old Rome. arose in the
air and antiquity herself threw off her dusty
rags, and arose in all the beauty OF youth.
| From the Neav MontklY Magazine.

| bearing and uuerrelsome disposition. His
duelling propensites, however kept him out
of all the first clubs in London, and render
ed him at once an object ofterror and of ha-
tired; and, even when he was introduced at
the Court of France, where single combat
was not SO much reprehended as IN Great
Britain. the young monarch (the unfortunate
Louis XVI.) could not help showing his ab-
horrence of protessed duelst. by utterlng
most deserved sarcasm on Fitzgerald, and
by refusing to admit him second time to
his lcvec. The gentleman who introduced
him (thc English Ambassador,) having
said, ~ have the honor to introduce to your
Majesty, Mr.. Fitzgerald, an Irishman of
high descent, who in his time, has success
lively fought no less than eighteen duels, and
always killed his man." the King replied,
"Monsieur l. l'Ambassadeur, have read your
famous English history of Jack the Giant
hiiler; and think it may be greatly improv-
ed by adding this Irishman's life, by way OF
appendix. Let him retire." His Majesty
! further observed to the Ambassador, in the
duelist's hearing, that if MIR. Fitzgerald
showed disposition to quarrel with any OF
his subjects, he should order him to quit
France in "a hours.


But to avoid further depression, the writer
has to state, that Fitzgerald having once ap-
Piled to Admiral Keith Stewart to propose
him as candidate for Brookcs' and the wor-
thy Admiral we'll knowing that he must Ell
ther fight or comply with his request, chose
the latter alternative. Accordingly, OH the
night in which the baloting was to take
place, (Which was only mere form in this
case, for even Keith Stewart himself had re-
solved to black ball him,) the dueilist ac-
companied the gallant Admiral to St. James
street, and waited in the room below whilst
the suffragcs were taking, in order to know
the issue.


The ballot was soon over, for without hes
itation each member threw in a black-baH,
and when the scrutiny took place, the COM
pany were not little amazed to find not c.
ven one white one among the whole num-
ber. However. the point being carried mem.
con. the grand affair now was, as to which
of the members had the hardihood TO an
nounce the same to the expectant candidate
No one would undertake the office, for the
announcement was sure to produce a chal-
lenge; and duel with fighting Fitzgerald
had in almost every case been fatal to his
opponents. The general opinion, however,
was, that the proposer. Admiral Stewart.
should convey the intelligence, and that in
as gen,eel terms as possible. But the Ad-
mral, who was certainly OIL all proper occa-
sions very gallant officer, was not inclined
! to go on any such embassy. mo gentlemen,
said he, proposed the fellow, because
knew you would not admit him; but have
no inclination to risk my life against that OF
ma(nan." "But, Admiral" replied the
Duke of Devonshire, "there being no white
ball in the box, he must know that youhaye
black balled him as well as the rest, and he
is sure to cali you out at all events" This
was poser for the poor Admiral, who sat,
silent for a few seconds, amidst the half
suppressed litter of the members; at length.
Joining in the laugh against himself, he ex-
claimed, upon my soul! pleasant job I've
got into. D--n the fellow!--No matter
wont go; let the waiter tell him that there
was one black ball, and his Dane must be
put up again if he wishes It," This plan ap-
pearcd so judcious, that all concurred in its
proprlety accordingly, he was, in few
minutes, despatched on the mission.


In the mean time, Mr.. Fitzgerald showed
evident symptoms of impatience. at being
kept SO long from his "dear friends" above
stairs; and frequently rang the bell to know
the state Of the poll. On the first occasion
he thus addressed the waiter who answered
his summons: "Come here, my tight little
| fellow; do you know if am chose yeti" Il
really can't say, sir, replied the young man;
but III sec." "There'sa nice nttle man.
be quick, dye see, and I'll give ye sixpence
when We come with the good news" Away
went the little man; but he was in no hurry
to come back, for he. as well AS all his fel-
lows, was sufficiently aware of Fitzgerald's
violent temper, and wished to come in con
tact with him as seldom as possible.


The bell rang again, and to another wal
ter the impatient candidate put the same
question-'Am / chose yet, 7vaiter?'-' Fhe
5allotting is not over yet, Sir replied the
man. Not over yeti exclaimed Fitzgerald.
But sure there is no use of balotting at all,
when my dear friends are unanimous for me
to come in.-Run, my man, and. let me know
how they are getting on


After the lapse of another quarter Of an
hour the bell rang so violently as to produce
a contest among the poor servants, as to
whose turn it was next to visit the lion in his
den; and MIR. Brooks seeing no alternative
but resolution. took the message from the
waiter who was descending the staircase.
and boldly entered the room with the coffee
ecuipagc in his hand. Ibid you call for cof-
fee, sir?' said Mr.. Brookes, smarty.-----
"D--n your coffee. snr, and you too.'' an
swercd Mr.. Fitzgerald in a voice which
made the hosts blood curdle in his veins; 81
want to know, sur. and tina, without one mo-
| pent's delav sur if Pm rhosr vetf'' siOh

you'll find me the best customer in your
house; but there must be small matter of
mistake in my election; and l should not
wish to be SO ungenteel as to take my safe a.
mong my dear friends up stairs until that
mistake is duly rectiied, you'll step up and
make my complimentsto the gentlemen, and
say as it is only mistake of one black ball,
they will be so good as to waive all ceremo-
ny on my account, and proceed to re-elect
their humble servant without any more de-
lay at all; SO now, my dear Mr.. Brookcs,
you may put down the coffee, and I'll be
drinking it while the new election is going
| on"


| Away went Mr.. Brookes, glad enough to
escape with whole bones for this time at
least. On the announcement of his errand
to the assembly above stairs, many Of the
members were panic struck; for they clear
| iy foresaw that some disagrceable circum-
stance was likely to be the finale of the farce
which they had been playing. Mr.. Brookes
stood silent for some minutes, waiting for
an answer, whilst several of the members
whispered and laughed, in groupes, at the
ludicrous figure which they all cut. At
length, the Earl of March, afterwards the
Duke of Queensbury, said aloud, d,--"Try the
effect of tzvo balls: hang his Irish impudence,
if two black balls dent take effect upon him,
don't know what wil.' This proposition
met with unanimous appreciation, and Mr..
Brookes was ordered to communicate it ac-
cording!y.


On re.entcring the waiting room, Mr..
Fitzgerald rose hastily from the chair, and
seizing him by the hand, eagerly inquired,
"Havr they elected me right now. Mr..
Brookesl" 81 hope no offence, Mr. Fitzge-
rald," said the landlord. "but am sorry to
Inform you, that the result of the second ball
loting is, that tsoo black balls were dropped
in, sir" "Sure then," exclaimed Fitzgerald.
s'there's now tzvo mistakes instead of one
Go back, my dear friend and tell the hon.
orabe members that it is very unciyil thing
to keep a gentleman waiting below stairs,
with no one to keep him company but HIM
self, whilst they are enjoying themselves
with their champagne, and their cards. and
their tokay, up above. Tell them to try it
again, and hope they will have better luck
next time, and make no more mistakes, be-
cause it is getting late, and zyontbe chose
tonight at all. So Mr.. Brookes be off with
yourself, and iave the door open till I see
what despatch you make"


Away went Mr.. Brookes for the last time.
On announcing his unwelceme errand. every
one saw that palliative measures only pro-
longed the dilemma; and General Fitzpat-
rick proposed, that Breokes should tell him
mis- Cause was iOl)SlCoob AOt hHdt HS hdo OCCA
black 6ailcd all oUer, from head to foot, and
it was hoped by all the members that Mr..
Fitzgerald would not persist in thurstng
himself into society where his company was
dsclned.'


This message, it was generally belived,
would prove sickener, as it certainly would
have done to any other candidate under SIM
liar circumstances. Not so however, to
Fitzgerald, who no sooner heard the pur-
port of it than he exclaimed, "Oh, Iperceive
it is mistake altogether, Mr.. Brookes, and
must see to the rectfying of it myself
there's nothing like daHng with principals,
and so I'll step up at once. and put this
thing to rights. without any more unneces-
sarv delay"


In spite Of Mr.. Brooks rcmonstrance,
that his entrance into che club room was a.
gaiust all rule and etiquette, Fitzgerald
found his way up stairs, threatening to
throw the landlord over the banisters for en-
deavoring to stop him. He entered the room
without any further ceremony than bow.
and saying to the members, who Indignantly
rose up xt this most unexpected intrusion,
Your servant gentlemen l beg you will
be sated." Walking up to the Fireplace,
he thus addressed Admiral Stewart $50,
my dear Admiral. Mr.. Brookes informs ME
that have been elected three times" "You
have been ballotted for, Mr., Fitzgerald. but
am sorry to say that you have not been
chosen" said Steward. Well, then" repli-
ed the duellist. "did you black-ball me!"--
my good SIR" answered the Admiral,
show could you suppose such thing"-
"Oh, suhhosed no such thing. my dear fell
low; only wanted to know who it was that
dropped the black balls in by accident as it
were"


Fitzgerald now went up to each individu-
al member, and put the same question ser'a-
tim, "Did you black-ball me, sur'" until he
made the round Of the whole club: and it
may we'll be supposed, that in every case ne
obtained similar answers to that OF the al
miral. When he had finished his inquis'-
ton, he thus addressed the whole body, who
preserved as dead and dread silence as the
urchns at parish school do on Saturday.
when the pedagogue orders A.,lf score Of
them to be horscd for neglectinE their catr-
chism, which they have to repeal to the par
son on Sunday :--"You see, gentlemen, that
as none of you have black -balled me, ! mast
be chose; and it is Misther Brookes that has
made the mistake. But was conyinced &C
it from the beginning, and am only sorry
that so much time has been lost, and honor
able gentlemen prevented from ENJOYING
each others company sooner. WanRsr!

Curious Historical FGcf.-During the
troubles in the reign of Charles the first. a
country girl came to I.ordon, in search OF
place as a servant mad, but not succeeding
she hired herself to carry out bear from IA
brew house, and was one ofthcsc called tub
wamen. The brewer observing good look
ing girl in this low occupation, took her in
to his family as servant; and after short
time married her; but he died while yet she
was young woman, and left her the bulk
Of his fortune. The business of the brewe-
ry was dropped, and 10 the young woman
was recommended Mr.. Hyde, as skilful
lawyer to arrange her husbands affairs
Hyde. who was afterwards the great Earl
of Clarendon, finding the widows fortune
very considerable. married her--of this mar
riagc there was no other issue than daugh.
ter, who was afterwards the wife of James
II. and mother of Mary and Anne, Queens
of England.

full articles.headline:
fpG9zMMSATa

From The Massachusetts, Yeoman.
THE WIFE-A SKETCH.
full articles.article:
DEATHS icy grasp was laid upon him now,
And ftfully beneath the tyrant's touch,
yifes current was congealing in his veins,
He was too weak to utter all his thoughts,
But some faint murlnuring from his lips escap'd,
Which none but she might hears yet still his


eyes,
Undimm'd spalse forth the fondness of his heart;
And vet sometimes would strange expression
Flash out beneath his dropping heavy lid,
And he would turn his eyes away from her,
And press convulsively her hand in his,
As tho some maddening thought shot thro' his


brain,
Then turn to her again a troubled look,
And send forth all his rising soul in one
Uncam yet fond and halfimploring glance.
What secret feeling crossed his bosom them
saw them once, when in their youthful prime,
When their first dreams of love and life were


bright
With hope, and fragrant flowers were springing


up


Along their pathway through smiling world,
No blightning fell upon their sunny hopes,
To bar the pledging or their hearts fond


thoughts,


And soon their mutual faith and VOWS were


scard-


She gave her heart, her all in confidence
To him who vow'd to love thro' veal or wo;
And when she fondly laid her head upon
His manly breast, she deem'd that o'cr their love
And bliss, no dark'ning cloud of fate would


comet
But though in youth within his heart no thought,
Save of her angel loveness then dwelt
And he had bowd his soul before the shrine,
In all the fond idolatry of love.


There came at last a change across their fate
For when the open gulelessness of youth
Had pass'd to manhood's darker brow Of care,
And he had mingled with the selfish crowd,
The stainless streams of early noble feeling
Changed their first freshness to ming taint;
And now the home that he was wont to call
His paradise was left for haun,s of mirth;
And he would hold his midnight revellings,
Startling the silence of the night by wild
And heartless joyance, till his heart had lost
All trace of purity-then HE him home,
And chide his once ador'd till she would weep,
An he would wake her infant then, to blend
1t wailing with her tears Of bitterness.
And she-,he injurd onc-her heart had swelled
In silence with IFS load of nk'rns griefs,
Until she might no longer keep it down
And then twas broken.-Yet she murmurd not,
Nor told her plant to any save to Heaven,
But calmly drank her bitter cup of wo;


And when her daily lot was still to bear
Unkindness and abuse, she answered not,
Save by her tears, and meeklv bore it all,
And strove TO still her agony ofheart.


And thus he held his waywarlncss to her,





Upon him; for the oft drain'd bowl at last
Had brought its never falling cnrse-and then
The strong endurance Of her love shone forth,
And, all her wrongs forgetting, she became
lowering angel round his couch of pain;
And without one reproaching word or look;
Fondy she tended him, as tho he ne'er
Had dash'd her cup of earthly happiness.-
And now his heart was soften'd and subdu'd:
ne felt that he had wrong'd her-and the stings
Of self.unbraidiner srnnte him he fhnuUht
upon her patient sufferancc of his hate,
And And how she was repaying all her wrongs
With fond devotedness when all the rest
forsook him in his hour of deepest need
And he would oftentimes have crav'd of her
forgiveness of his ills-but she would stop
his words, and with smile would say to him
me past was buried in oblivion.
hut now he felt that life was ebbing fast,
And that he could not leave the world in peace,
without he easd his bosom of its load
ofguilt-and therefore had his eyes such wild
and troubled looks; and when he took her hand
from off his brow, and laid it on her breast,
20 20 still the beatings of her bursting heart,
ra'h'rlng his Weekend powers, so as to throw
INTO INTO, his last attempt some strength of mind,
WI WITH tone so changed from that of by-past time,
mat mat she half started at its hollow sound,
nc sad; 81 know that soon my heart must stop
.s beatings, and be still at deaths cold touch
1nV-hearme now--for l must speak this once,
now now have wrong'd thee, and to pray that this
my MY last departing hour may hear thee bless
NO. Mono that dare not ask thy blessing
aay hear thee pardon him whose tortur'd heart
ran well aton'd for all its crimes,-if pain


ana suffering can atonement make for sin.


tcannot tell thee all that fills my breast,


90. oryoce and sight are falling fast way


S''oP down, and look once more as thou were
,o wont,


n ntnou wilt pardon me.'' She knelt beside


ins bed, and laid her pallid cheek on his,


Th Tha Kindly said, "Oh, speak not thus my love
rhe past IS all forgotten;-nay look up


-"ou must not leave me now."-A groan burs


forth


nan. ms IS too kind-my heart will burst-one kiss


'' p'e's Observation-Disclosures own''--

full articles.headline: TIE LADIES, FRIEND.
full articles.article:
Almost all women are captivated by talent;
especially those for whose pleasure, in par
ticular, its possessor may exert it. Nothing
can be more delightful to them, because no.
thing can be more flattering; and fiattery is
the key to all hearts. Want OF handsome
person, or even of good looks. is for the
most part forgotten, or willingly pardoned,
in the man of talent. The eye of woman
does not require to be dazzled as well as her
mind; Il speak of general instances.) The
same cannot be said of virtuous qualities
In SO much higher esteem does human vani-
ty hold talent than virtue. Good looks,
combined with vapd intellect. will win few
women, unless they are equally vapid with
the object of their admiration.
